DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

World Health Organisation Chief Tedros said there has been concerning incidents of onwards spread of the virus in people with no history of travel to China. (Newswires)

Chinese President Xi said China will adopt more decisive measures to contain the spread of the virus in the Hubei province and will be speeding up development of clinically effective drugs, while he also stated that they will be making economic adjustments in order to mitigate the impact of the coronavirus outbreak and are to stabilise consumption, according to state TV. (Newswires)

China's Wuhan Party Chief said the city has still not completed their confirmation of all existing suspected cases and aims to test all suspected cases in the region by tomorrow. (Newswires)

China will speed up the provision of medicines which display clinical effects within the coronavirus outbreak according to State Media, while there were separate reports that a candidate vaccine targeting the novel coronavirus has been tested on animals, according to sources with the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention. (Newswires/Xinhua)

Global Times suggested that the incubation period for the coronavirus may be longer than was previously thought as a patient with no symptoms for 17 days was diagnosed with the virus. (Global Times)

China's Finance Ministry state they will continue to implement both tax and fee cuts in 2020, with such cuts exceeding 2.3trl in 2019.In other news, over 300 firms are seeking a total of at least CNY 57bln in loans to soften the impact from coronavirus according to sources. (Newswires)

White House Trade Advisor Navarro noted that the coronavirus outbreak shows the need to bring back more drugs and medical supply manufacturing to the US, while he added that China will have to be held accountable for the outbreak. (Newswires)

China's imports of US goods are likely to decline over 10% Y/Y in Q1 amid the coronavirus outbreak, although there would be a rebound in bilateral trade in Q2 if the epidemic is contained in a timely manner, according to Global Times source poll. (Twitter)

Foxconn (2317 TT) received approval to resume partial production at its key plant in Shenzhen, according to sources. (Newswires)

IMF's Japan Mission Chief Cashin said the spread of the coronavirus poses risk to the Japanese economy (tourism, retail, trade and investment) and urges BoJ to conduct a comprehensive review of its policy objectives. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

EU member states have made some additions to the EU's mandate for talks with the UK including extra references to level playing field which should develop over time and uphold existing fishing rights, according to BBC's Fleming. (Twitter)

US President Trump said it is time to negotiate "very seriously" with the EU on trade. (AFP)

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC's JTC recommended extending voluntary production adjustments under the ‘Declaration of Cooperation’ process until the end of 2020 and to proceed with an additional adjustment until the end of the Q2. (Newswires)

Algeria Energy Minister said OPEC and Non-OPEC states remain in discussions over the JTC's recommendation to extend the output cut, according to state media. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump stated to aides that he does not want to have another summit with North Korea's Kim. (CNN)

North Korea continued to enhance its nuclear and ballistic missile programmes in 2019 in violation of UN sanctions, according to a confidential UN report. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Harker (Voter, Neutral) said central bank should hold rates steady for a while and watch how developments as well as the data unfold before taking action. Harker also stated that the economy is in good shape and expects economic growth of 2%, while he added inflation is on track to achieve the 2% target. Furthermore, Harker added they would need to discuss the economy if coronavirus situation worsens although it is not currently at that point and he suggested that a rate cut would not do anything to boost business investment. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (Non-voter, Neutral) said inflation a bit above target is 'far better' than a bit below in today's environment and noted historically low unemployment does not mean labour market is historically tight, while she added that lower inflation and rates mean less monetary policy space is available to fight the next downturn. (Newswires)

US President Trump proposed USD 4.8trln budget which suggests a reduction in social-safety-net programmes and foreign aid, whilst it is said to raise outlays for defense and veterans. (WSJ)

US Senator Bernie Sanders formally requested a partial recount of the Iowa caucus results. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Tesla (TSLA) initially opened 9% higher as its production restarted in China and, as a speculative M&A Forbes piece suggested, it could be a target for Google at USD 1,500; however, gains were short-lived, and TSLA ended the session with gains of ~4%. AMD (AMD) was firmer on reports that suggested Apple (AAPL) could begin using AMD processors for Macs, replacing Intel (INTC), reported Street Insider. Amazon (AMZN) has tapped a Sony (SNE) executive, Mike Hopkins, to lead its Prime Video, Movie and TV Studios. General Motors (GM) was named as Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas’s best pick, noting its zero-emission plan has the potential to push the stock to USD 100. Biogen (BIIB) was lower following a poor Alzheimer’s trial with Eli-Lilly (LLY) which failed to meet its primary endpoint; neither did a study from Roche (ROGN SW). Apple (AAPL) opened lower following reports its cheaper iPhone may have to be postponed due to the coronavirus, but later rose with risk appetite. Apple key supplier Foxconn (2354 TT) came back to production today at one of its largest plants; however, source reports suggested only 10% of its workforce had returned. Initially, its Shenzhen plant had not opened, although source reports stated it has now received approval to resume partial production at the key plant. Slack (WORK) caught a bid on reports it had gained IBM (IBM) as a customer – its largest. S&P 500 +0.73% at 3352, Dow +0.60% at 29,277, NDX +1.23% at 9517.

The TPLEX was bid on Monday as woes continued to linger on the coronavirus outbreak and its transmission globally. Desks note the "wash out" of speculative shorts ahead of a duration heavy US Treasury issuance schedule for the week (3s, 10s, and 30s), additionally, with the majority of S&P 500 constituents now out of their earnings blackout, further IG corporate supply can be expected. The T-Note found its lows in the overnight before the Western front came and brought it back to highs as equity futures drifted lower somewhat before the cash open. However, the equity complex turned positive not long after the open, coinciding with strength in the greenback, keeping the 10-year yield anchored around 1.56% for a short while before it continued to move lower through till settlement, taking it just beneath 1.55%; curve spreads were little changed, with the belly seeing a slightly larger bid than the short and long end. US T-note futures (H20) settled 9 ticks higher at 131-11+.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 10th February 2020: Stocks set ATHs, ignoring risk-off signal seen in other assets
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 10th February 2020: Stocks set ATHs, ignoring risk-off signal seen in other assets

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar up, Crude down.

* REAR VIEW: Coronavirus outbreak sees China taking new measures amid some production resuming in the country; no decision on the OPEC front

* COMING UP: Events/Data: US NFIB Business Optimism, JOLTS, Redbook; NY Fed Q4 2019 Household Debt and Credit Report; UK Q4 GDP (Prelim.), Goods Trade Balance; US Private Energy Inventories. Speakers: Fed’s Powell, Kashkari, Quarles, Bullard; ECB’s Lagarde, Schnabel, Lane; BoE’s Carney, Haskel, Cunliffe. Auctions: US 3-year Note. Earnings: D, EXC, PGR, HLT, DISH, WMB, UAA; DAI GY.

 

* CORONAVIRUS: China confirmed 3062 new coronavirus cases and 97 deaths on February 9th, compared to 2656 new cases and 89 deaths on February 8th, with the total confirmed cases now at 40,171 and total deaths at 908 as of February 9th, coming ahead of Monday where some firms are returning to operations. The Chinese Commerce Ministry said there is no reason to adopt intervention policies on international trade amid the outbreak - echoing prior WHO commentary. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi said China will adopt more decisive measures to contain the spread of the virus in the Hubei province and will be speeding up the development of clinically effective drugs. Xi added that Beijing’s city government should take targeted measures to curb the increasing risk of the spread of the virus after the return from holiday; additionally, Xi said they are to prevent large-scale layoffs, and the long-term improving momentum of the Chinese economy has not changed. State media also reported that it would speed up the provision of medicines that display clinical effects within the coronavirus outbreak. Asia trade was subdued on Monday, but not tumultuous, with desks noting a decline in the growth rate of cases, although some also draw attention to the validity/accuracy of the figures, participants are finding some solace in the CPC’s latest containment measures. Additionally, the PBoC is maintaining its stimulative policy, announcing it would be offering the first round of special re-lending funds to combat the coronavirus, becoming available weekly to banks later this month. Furthermore, an advisor hinted that the PBoC could cut its deposit rate but gave little further details.

* FED: Fed's Harker (voter, neutral) said the Fed should hold rates steady for a while; should watch how developments and data unfold before acting. On the economy, Harker said it is in good shape and expects economic growth of 2%; adding it is on track to achieve the 2% inflation target. Expects unemployment rate to stay below 4% for the next few years; mortgage refinancing could support consumer spending this year. More widely, the Philly Fed President said the negative effects of the coronavirus on the Chinese economy are something to watch, while uncertainty over fiscal policies, trade and geopolitical tensions are holding back business investment, he added. Fed’s Bowman (voter, neutral) reiterated that she sees a favourable US outlook of moderate growth, low unemployment and inflation rising to its target level.

* ECB: ECB’s de Guindos stated the ECB has the tools and willingness to use them if necessary, noting interest rates can be lowered further, the volume of debt purchases can rise, as could liquidity injections. De Guindos, however, caveated the dovish comments stating the side effects are increasingly evident.

* CHINA CPI (JAN.): Headline CPI rose 5.4% in January from December’s 4.5%, topping estimates for an increase of 4.9%. The rise in prices was largely driven by the effects of the Spring Festival, coupled with the impacts of the coronavirus outbreak, according to the National Bureau of Statistics – food prices rose 20.6% YY (Prev. 17.4%) while non-food prices rose 1.6%, up from the prior of 1.3%. Linking this to the coronavirus, Hubei Province - the epicentre of the nCoV epidemic, saw CPI rising 5.5% YY – which analysts note is relatively in-line with the country’s growth and thus reflects constructive measures taken the Chinese governments on securing supply and stabilising prices. Elsewhere PPI rose in-line with expectations at 0.1%, rising from negative 0.5%.

* WTI (H0) SETTLED USD 0.75 LOWER AT USD 49.57/BBL; BRENT (J0) SETTLED USD 1.20 LOWER AT USD 53.27/BBL: The crude complex was offered on Monday, extending Friday’s losses as participants ponder both the economic and sentiment impact from the coronavirus outbreak – seeing WTI/Brent arb. hit a multi-year low. Prices also struggled to find support on the OPEC front, Azerbaijan’s Energy Minister pushed back against holding an early OPEC+ meeting, while Russian Energy Minister Novak also noted that Russia is not yet prepared to reveal its stance regarding measures. Following the OPEC JTC meeting last week, the committee announced in a press release that it recommended extending voluntary production adjustments under the ‘Declaration of Cooperation’ process until the end of 2020 and to proceed with an additional adjustment until the end of the second quarter; more specifically, separate sources report the proposed figure stood at an additional 600k BPD cut - Algeria’s Energy Minister said later that OPEC and Non-OPEC were still in discussions considering the JTC’s recommendation. Separately, according to Iraqi officials, the US has extended its waiver to Iraq to import Iranian energy, again, by for this time 120 days, with the officials noting Washington’s satisfaction with Iraq’s ongoing efforts to move to energy sufficiency. Looking ahead to this week’s US energy inventories, expectations (bbls) see crude +2.9mln, distillates -0.6mln, gasoline +0.7mln and Genscape sees Cushing stocks +2.3mln. Additionally, attention draws to the monthly reports from EIA, OPEC and IEA on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday respectively, with particular focus on any changes to 2020 oil demand forecasts.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (H20) SETTLED 9 TICKS HIGHER AT 131-11+: The TPLEX was bid on Monday as woes continued to linger on the coronavirus outbreak and its transmission globally. Desks note the "wash out" of speculative shorts ahead of a duration heavy US Treasury issuance schedule for the week (3s, 10s, and 30s), additionally, with the majority of S&P 500 constituents now out of their earnings blackout, further IG corporate supply can be expected. The T-Note found its lows in the overnight before the Western front came and brought it back to highs as equity futures drifted lower somewhat before the cash open. However, the equity complex turned positive not long after the open, coinciding with strength in the greenback, keeping the 10-year yield anchored around 1.56% for a short while before it continued to move lower through till settlement, taking it just beneath 1.55%; curve spreads were little changed, with the belly seeing a slightly larger bid than the short and long end.

* BREXIT: UK Foreign Minister Raab said a Singapore deal will be one of the first waves of free trade agreements (FTA) and wants a deal over the line ASAP, while Raab also stated the UK plans to start trade negotiations with Japan before spring and complete an FTA by year-end. In related news, the UK is reportedly planning to announce locations of as many as ten freeports this year. EU member states are reportedly toughening their demands for 'status quo' access to UK fishing waters post-Brexit, Telegraph reported. Norwegian PM Soldberg has warned Britain that Brexit should not be utilised as an opportunity to shut out other countries from fishing in British waters.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 +0.73% at 3352, Dow +0.60% at 29,277, NDX +1.23% at 9517. SECTORS: Cons Disc +1.26%, Cons Stpl +0.37%, Energy -0.81%, Financials +0.21%, Health +0.51%, Industrials +0.56%, Materials +0.01%, Real Estate +1.23%, Technology +1.35%, Communication Svs +0.83%, Utilities +0.34%.

* EARNINGS: Loews (L) traded higher following a decent quarter. Allergan (AGN) also higher following top and bottom-line beats. Restaurant Brands (QSR) made gains after a revenue miss, but EPS came in above expectations and although Burger King and Tim Horton SSS missed expectations, it saw very strong Popeye SSS +34.4%, primarily driven by its chicken sandwich.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Tesla (TSLA) initially opened 9% higher as its production restarted in China and, as a speculative M&A Forbes piece suggested, it could be a target for Google at USD 1,500; however, gains were short-lived, and TSLA ended the session with gains of ~4%. AMD (AMD) was firmer on reports that suggested Apple (AAPL) could begin using AMD processors for Macs, replacing Intel (INTC), reported Street Insider. Amazon (AMZN) has tapped a Sony (SNE) executive, Mike Hopkins, to lead its Prime Video, Movie and TV Studios. General Motors (GM) was named as Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas’s best pick, noting its zero-emission plan has the potential to push the stock to USD 100. Biogen (BIIB) was lower following a poor Alzheimer’s trial with Eli-Lilly (LLY) which failed to meet its primary endpoint; neither did a study from Roche (ROGN SW). Apple (AAPL) opened lower following reports its cheaper iPhone may have to be postponed due to the coronavirus, but later rose with risk appetite. Apple key supplier Foxconn (2354 TT) came back to production today at one of its largest plants; however, source reports suggested only 10% of its workforce had returned. Initially, its Shenzhen plant had not opened, although source reports stated it has now received approval to resume partial production at the key plant. Slack (WORK) caught a bid on reports it had gained IBM (IBM) as a customer – its largest.

* M&A: Simon Property Group (SPG) confirmed it is to acquire Taubman Centers (TCO), with an offer with a 50% premium to last Friday’s closing price, offering USD 52.50/shr. Xerox (XRX) increased its bid for HP Inc (HPQ) by USD 2 to USD 24/shr. L Brands (LB) is reportedly near a deal with Sycamore Partners for its Victoria Secret brand, where a deal could potentially be announced this week.

* FX WRAP: USD continued its gain finding technical resistance at 98.885, a level it resides of heading into Asia trade. The gains follow on from strong US data last week, ahead of Powell’s semi-annual testimonies this week and the NH caucus tomorrow. MUFG highlight the relative attractiveness of the buck has been increased in the near term as concerns on growth outlook outside the US rise as Germany continues to see weak data, such as a -3.5% fall in industrial production, and despite the turnaround in business survey’s, it has not been backed by hard data. Meanwhile the coronavirus continues to dampen the outlook for growth. The desk also highlights an increased probability of President Trump winning a second term and further evidence of a resilient economy, as seen in last week’s NFP and ISM reports. Petro currencies CAD & RUB trade flat against the buck after giving up initial strength as oil prices continued to sell. Elsewhere for the Loonie, Scotia believes “USDCAD is overshooting Fair Value by quite a margin and that the USD rally is showing signs of faltering”. CNH outpaced USD gains amid a firmer CPI which saw USDCNH fall back beneath the 7.00 figure. EURUSD fell amid broad dollar strength which saw a technical break through the 8th Oct. low at 1.0939 to find support just above the key 1.09 figure. If 1.09 were to give way, technicians are eyeing 1.0879, 8th Oct. low, as the next level of support. GBP firmer today despite further bearish Brexit headlines which suggest the EU is adding further additions to the EU’s mandate. JPY saw a relatively uneventful session all day and remains flat against the buck but above 109.50, UBS note it prefers to be long risk overall, suggesting a stop loss beneath 109-109.50, while noting topside resistance at 110. XAU traded firmer today and remains around the 1575 handle with UBS highlighting resistance above at 1582, and support at 1565. EMFX was generally mixed. TRY was firmer following capital control intervention to stem TRY losses, which initially saw it cross beneath the 6.00 figure although lost most of its gains amid broad dollar strength and ongoing geopolitical concerns with Syria.

* TURKEY CAPITAL CONTROLS: Turkey has further tightened control on the Lira in which regulators cut the limit for Turkish banks’ FX swap, spot and forward transactions with foreign entities to 10% of a bank’s equity, down from the prior of 25%.  The moves announced by the banking regulator is aimed at limiting foreign speculators following last week’s weakness in the Turkish currency. The intervention by Turkey coincided with weekend military action which saw increased personnel and military equipment support sent to Syria’s Idlib region ahead of confrontation on Monday. The prospect of coordinated government and Central Bank action, as ever with Turkey, cannot be ruled out. Desks note that while the measure had some success in making it difficult for hedge funds short the TRY, it has also deterred investors from holding Turkish assets.

Prices also struggled to find support on the OPEC front, Azerbaijan’s Energy Minister pushed back against holding an early OPEC+ meeting, while Russian Energy Minister Novak also noted that Russia is not yet prepared to reveal its stance regarding measures. Following the OPEC JTC meeting last week, the committee announced in a press release that it recommended extending voluntary production adjustments under the ‘Declaration of Cooperation’ process until the end of 2020 and to proceed with an additional adjustment until the end of the second quarter; more specifically, separate sources report the proposed figure stood at an additional 600k BPD cut - Algeria’s Energy Minister said later that OPEC and Non-OPEC were still in discussions considering the JTC’s recommendation. Separately, according to Iraqi officials, the US has extended its waiver to Iraq to import Iranian energy, again, by for this time 120 days, with the officials noting Washington’s satisfaction with Iraq’s ongoing efforts to move to energy sufficiency. Looking ahead to this week’s US energy inventories, expectations (bbls) see crude +2.9mln, distillates -0.6mln, gasoline +0.7mln and Genscape sees Cushing stocks +2.3mln. Additionally, attention draws to the monthly reports from EIA, OPEC and IEA on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday respectively, with particular focus on any changes to 2020 oil demand forecasts.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar back in the ascendency after shallow pull-back
content:
USD

Continuing the recent pattern of trade, a brief interlude has prefaced more broad Greenback gains, albeit allied to weakness in certain rival currencies or in fact due to more pronounced weakness elsewhere. Regardless, the DXY has resumed its almost relentless advance and is inching even closer towards the next technical resistance level ahead of the 98.000 handle at 98.885 (vs 98.857 high so far) before attention returns to the Fed for speeches from Daly and Harker. However, Chairman Powell’s upcoming semi-annual testimonies could be pivotal in terms of the Buck’s fortunes and direction, barring any further external factors.

EUR/NZD/CAD

All on the back foot, with the Euro unable to hold above near term chart support vs the US Dollar or withstand a strong rebound in the Pound for that matter. Indeed, Eur/Usd saw stops tripped when 1.0941 gave way and extended declines through 1.1000 to circa 1.0912, while Eur/Gbp reversed from just over 0.8500 to sub-0.8450 at one stage. Meanwhile, the Kiwi remains wary about a possible dovish RBNZ hold at the February policy meet, as Nzd/Usd slips back under 0.6400 and the Kiwi also loses ground vs its Antipodean peer even though the boost from Chinese inflation data overnight has dissipated. Similarly, the Loonie has not gleaned much traction from better than forecast Canadian housing data in the form of starts and building permits, as Usd/Cad trades much nearer the top of 1.3289-1.3329 parameters and another downturn in crude prices may be weighing on top of warnings from Finance Minister Monreau about the adverse impact of China’s coronavirus on the domestic economy.

NOK/GBP/AUD/JPY/CHF 

In contrast to the Loonie, much stronger than expected Norwegian CPI kept the Norwegian Crown elevated within a 10.1930-10.1090 range, while Sterling’s aforementioned revival was far less easy to fathom or put down to any positive catalyst given mainly bearish looking Brexit headlines and reports, like the EU and France hardening criteria for post-transition UK trade/relationship terms. Nonetheless, Cable reclaimed 1.2900+ status ahead of a raft of domestic data on Tuesday, unlike the Aussie that failed to sustain momentum forged from China’s CPI and PPI releases as noted above, as Aud/Usd lost grip of 0.6700. Elsewhere, the Yen and Franc held very tight lines vs the Greenback around 109.75 and 0.6775 respectively, with the former shrugging off BoJ critique from the IMF and latter taking mixed Swiss inflation in stride.

EM

Eventful sessions for most regional currencies against the backdrop of renewed Dollar strength, but with the Try also bolstered by official intervention and buffeted by more investor jitters over Turkey’s military exchanges with Russian Syrian army forces. Meanwhile, the Huf had to contend with comments from the NBH about an impending liquidity squeeze without more downsizing of the Hungarian Central Bank’s swap portfolio.

subject: US indices are marginally higher with outperformance seen in defensive sectors. Tesla (TSLA) is up +6% as production restarts in China and as a speculative M&A Forbes piece suggested it could be a target for Google
content:
Gainers

  • Tesla (TSLA) +6% as production resumes at its Shanghai plant, whilst a piece in Forbes suggests TSLA could be a takeover target for Google (GOOG)
  • HP Inc (HPQ) +3% as Xerox (XRX) raises its takeover offer to USD 24/shr from USD 22/shr
  • Loews (L) +3.5% on EPS beats whilst revenue also picked up

Losers

  • Eli Lilly (LLY) -3% as its Alzheimer’s trial failed to meet its primary endpoint, also weighing on Biogen (BIIB)
  • Trip.com (TCOM) -3.5% amid continued coronavirus fears to the travel industry
  • YUM China (YUMC) -1.7% as one of its employees who handles food preparation was confirmed to have the coronavirus
analysis_details: US indices initially opened lower, although are now in positive territory with Tesla (TSLA) leading the gains as production restarts in China and as a speculative M&A Forbes piece suggested it could be a target for Google (GOOG). Sectors paint a defensive picture with Consumer Discretionary, Real Estate and Consumer Staples leading. Consumer Discretionary is being driven by gains in L Brands who trade with gains of 1.7% after reports suggested it is nearing a deal with Sycamore Partners to sell its Victoria Secret brand. On the downside, energy continues to underperform following the fall in oil prices recently amid demand concerns surrounding the coronavirus, and a lack of OPEC+ consensus on production cuts to stem the slide, whilst it also appears there will be no early review meeting. Financials are also a relative sector underperformer opening with losses of 0.2% due to lower yields across the curve.

Barron’s also highlighted the top 10 sustainable US companies as: Agilent (A), Texas Instruments (TXN), Voya Financial (VOYA), Tiffany (TIF), Best Buy (BBY), HP Inc. (HPQ), Cisco (CSCO), WW Grainger (GWW), Avnet (AVT), and Autodesk (ADSK). Elsewhere, Barron’s state that General Motors (GM) note investors give little credit to the automaker for the huge amount of cash it generates, noting it is more tech forward than some realise as it is highly invested autonomous driving technology, just like Tesla (TSLA). Other Barron’s articles were positive on First Cash (FCFS), noting it will perform well in downturns, and Kraft Heinz (KHC), noting its valuation is cheap and the new management should succeed in stabilising the top line and divesting assets.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 10th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are subdued but have been bolstered, alongside sentiment in general, by comments out of China regarding coronavirus medicine provisions
  • Chinese President Xi says China will adopt more decisive measures to contain the spread of the virus in the Hubei province, and will be speeding up development of clinically effective drugs
  • Chinese Commerce Ministry says there is no reason to adopt intervention polices on international trade amid the coronavirus outbreak
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia is not yet prepared to announce its position on OPEC+ actions
  • Azerbaijani oil Minister downplayed the prospect of an early OPEC+ meeting
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Fed’s Daly and Harker

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China confirmed 3062 new coronavirus cases and 97 deaths on February 9th vs. 2656 new cases and 89 deaths on February 8th, with the total confirmed cases now at 40171 and total deaths at 908 as of February 9th. (Newswires)

Chinese Commerce Ministry says there is no reason to adopt intervention polices on international trade amid the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

China will speed up the provision of medicines which display clinical effects within the coronavirus outbreak, according to State Media. (Newswires) Note, this comment did coincide with remarks via other sources that China is aiming 'breakthrough in drugs for coronavirus' and are to prioritise coronavirus control in the Hubei region, according to Radio reports

Chinese President Xi says China will adopt more decisive measures to contain the spread of the virus in the Hubei province, and will be speeding up development of clinically effective drugs, according to state TV; Beijing city Gov't should take targeted measures to curb the increasing risk of the spread of the virus after the return from holiday.

-        Are to prevent large-scale layoffs, and the long-term improving momentum of the Chinese economy has not changed

Japan cruise ship has about 60 more coronavirus infections to bring the total to 130. (Newswires)

China is spending at least USD 10bln to control the coronavirus outbreak and is reaching out for medical supplies from other nations, while it was also reported that the World Health Organization is sending an advanced team to China to investigate the coronavirus. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac stocks began the week with a sombre tone due to concerns regarding the ongoing coronavirus epidemic which has surpassed the death toll from the SARS outbreak, and following last Friday’s losses on Wall St where markets pulled back from record highs but still notched the best weekly performance since June last year. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s tech and energy sectors although downside in the index was stemmed by resilience in gold miners and defensives, while the Tokyo benchmark recouped some of the opening losses on favourable currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) were cautious due to the rising infected numbers and as some businesses resumed operations, although the mainland showed some early resilience amid continued PBoC efforts including the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus and CNY 900bln of reverse repo operations to sustain liquidity levels. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the cautious risk appetite in the region and with the BoJ present in the market in which it upped the purchases in 10yr-25yr maturities.   

PBoC injected CNY 700bln via 7-day and CNY 200bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position, while the PBoC announced to offer the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus on Monday and will offer the facility weekly to banks later in the month. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9863 vs. Exp. 6.9829 (Prev. 6.9768)

PBoC could potentially cut its deposit rate, according to an advisor - details remain light. (Newswires)

China Global Times tweeted a good number of Chinese companies will scoop back to business operations although companies need to take the safety of their workers as the top priority, while it later tweeted that many SMEs in China will not restart business today due to shortage of protective supplies. (Twitter)

Chinese CPI (Jan) Y/Y 5.4% vs. Exp. 4.9% (Prev. 4.5%) Chinese PPI (Jan) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. -0.5%)

UK/EU

UK Foreign Minister Raab said a Singapore deal will be one of the first wave of free trade agreements and wants a deal over the line ASAP, while Raab also stated the UK plans to start trade negotiations with Japan before spring and complete an FTA by year-end. In related news, the UK is reportedly planning to announce locations of as many as 10 freeports this year. (Newswires) EU member states are reportedly toughening their demands for 'status quo' access to UK fishing waters post-Brexit. (Telegraph) Norwegian PM Soldberg has warned Britain that Brexit should not be utilised as an opportunity to shut out other countries from fishing in British waters. (Politico)

UK PM Johnson is expected, on Tuesday, to announce his decision on the HS2 rail line; with UK Sunday Papers reporting that the London to Birmingham section will go ahead, but remaining sections will be under review. Separately, a Cabinet reshuffle is expected to occur prior to the Easter recess on Thursday. (Politico)

UK Chancellor Javid is considering a large tax increase on higher earners in the March budget. (FT) Furthermore, the Chancellor is also considering limiting tax relief on pension contributions to 20% and introducing a “recurring” wealth tax on the owners of expensive homes. (Telegraph)

Senior Conservative’s have written to Conservative MPs highlighting concerns around Huawei’s role in the UK’s 5G network, wanting ‘high risk’ Co’s to be ruled out immediately or alternatively phased out over time. Subsequently, China’s UK ambassador to the UK has criticised these comments, and the 35% cap that has been placed on Huawei’s involvement in the 5G network. (BBC)

The “Boris bounce” will be dampened by the disruption caused to the global economy from the coronavirus outbreak, economists have warned. (Telegraph)

EU’s efforts to hammer out a budget deal by the end of February is reportedly at risk of being de-railed by widening divisions between richer and poorer member states, according to diplomats. European Council President Michel is convening an EU leaders’ summit on February 20th in an attempt to negotiate on the seven-year EU budget - which must be settled by year-end. (FT)

Irish PM Varadkar’s Fine Gael party is seen taking 36 seats, while Fianna Fail is seen to win 45 seats and Sinn Fein at 37 seats in Ireland’s snap general election. (Newswires)

ECB’s de Guindos says we have tools and willingness to use them if necessary. We can lower interest rates further, increase the volume of debt purchases or increase liquidity injections, but the side effects are increasingly evident. That is why we continually insist that it is now up to other actors to come into play. (ECB)

EZ Sentix Index (Feb) 5.2 vs. Exp. 4.1 (Prev. 7.6)

-        Sentix Chief Huebner notes "in view of the significant declines in Chinese economic data, it is clear that the negative effect is likely to be much greater if it does not become apparent in the coming days that the spread of the virus has been taken away."

-        While morale deteriorated in Asia and the EZ, the US showed resilience

Bank of France Business Sentiment 96 vs. Exp. 97 - sees Q1 GDP growth of 0.3% (vs. -0.1% in Q4 2019). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Overall a lacklustre start to the week for European equities [Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%] following on from a gloomy APAC session as investors continued to weigh ramifications of the nCoV outbreak in which the death toll exceeded that of the SARS outbreak. Some desks note that this week will be crucial to see if the outbreak morphs into a pandemic (a global epidemic). Back to Europe, bourses are mixed with some mild impetus derived from headlines which reaffirmed China’s commitment to find a breakthrough in drugs for the pathogen (although price action was somewhat fleeting), whilst sectors also broadly mixed with no clear reflection of the overall sentiment. In terms of individual movers, NMC Health (+11.0%) leads the gains in the pan-European index after sources noted that the Co. is in talks with KKR regarding a potential deal, albeit KKR is having trouble fixing a price amid the recent volatility in NMC share prices – a ballpark figure of GBP 2bln is touted. Further, the source added that KKR might face competition from other US-based PE firms. Italian-listed Exor (+6.0%) remains a top gainer in the Stoxx 600 after source reports that Covea is reportedly in discussions regarding the acquisition of the Exor-controlled PartnerRe in an all-cash deal valued at USD 9bln - subsequently, Scor (-2.8%) shares trade lower as Covea hold some 8.5% of Scor. Elsewhere on the downside, Roche (-0.5%) shares are subdued as its top-line results for an Alzheimer’s treatment did not reach a primary endpoint.

China’s Shenzhen has rejected a request by Taiwan’s Foxconn to resume production at its key plant in the city, Shenzhen will check the Co’s plant again to ensure measures are properly in place, according to sources. (Newswires) Note, Foxconn are a Apple (AAPL) supplier.

Researcher Trendforce has cut its Q1 2020 global smartphone production forecast to -12% YY amid the coronavirus outbreak and Q1 2020 global production is seen at a 5yr low at 275mln units. (Newswires)

General Motors (GM) - will be restarting production in China from February 15th. (Newswires)

FX

NOK/AUD - The clear G10 outperformers and both fuelled by CPI data, albeit indirectly in the case of the latter. Eur/Nok has recoiled sharply on the back of significantly stronger than expected Norwegian headline and core inflation that was boosted by higher food prices, transport costs and other services items, while Aud/Usd has rebounded on the coat-tails of the Yuan in wake of Chinese CPI beating consensus by some distance and PPI printing positive in y/y terms for the first time in 7 years. The Norwegian Krona is hovering around 10.1300 against the Euro within circa 10.1930-10.1090 parameters and the Aussie is trying to regain grip of the 0.6900 handle vs its US counterpart, as Usd/Cnh pulls back a bit further from recent 7.0000+ peaks despite the PBoC’s firmer Usd/Cny midpoint fix overnight.

GBP/NZD - Sterling has recovered pretty well from another bout of selling pressure that pushed Cable back below 1.2900 and Eur/Gbp over 0.8500 again, but the rationale for the recovery appears as uncertain as the catalyst for the early EU session declines, suggesting technical factors and/or spec positioning looking for sustained Pound weakness that simply failed to materialise. Elsewhere, the Kiwi is pivoting 0.6400 against its US rival, but lagging in Aud/Nzd cross terms ahead of Wednesday’s RBNZ policy meeting even though the prospect of any change in the benchmark rate is deemed remote, and an element of caution could be warranted given a greater chance that guidance may be skewed towards further easing, if warranted and China’s coronavirus causes more widespread contagion.

EUR/CAD/JPY/CHF - All narrowly mixed and rangebound vs the Greenback, as the DXY holds just shy of last Friday’s 97.722 post-NFP high and between 97.709-599, with Eur/Usd tightly bound around 1.0950 irrespective of more poor Eurozone data and political angst (only this time roles somewhat reversed as Italian IP plummeted and Germany’s CDU party leader opts not to run for Chancellor). Similarly, the Loonie is straddling 1.3300 ahead of Canada’s LEI and housing data, while the Yen is holding off recent lows and rebound highs amidst latest reports of a potential anti nCoV ‘breakthrough’ and Franc flitting either side of 0.6775/1.0700 against the Euro after mixed Swiss CPI reads vs expectations and weekly sight deposits.

EM - Broad rebounds against the Dollar, but with the Lira only really stopping the rot with the aid of intervention and capital controls following Turkey’s BDDK lowering bank currency swap and FX forward limits to 10% from 25% previously. Usd/Try meandering from 6.0145 to 5.9775 or thereabouts.

Norwegian Consumer Price Index YY (Jan) 1.8% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.4%)

-        Norwegian Core Inflation YY (Jan) 2.9% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.8%)

Turkey banking watchdog BDDK said it was lowering the limit for Turkish banks’ forex swap, spot and forward transactions with foreign entities to 10% of a bank’s equity from Prev. 25%. (Newswires)

Notable FX Option Expiries, NY Cut:

-        AUD/USD: 0.6625 (1.4BLN), 0.6750 (920M)

FIXED INCOME

Bonds are off best levels, but still bid/underpinned with the core Eurozone debt future leading the way, albeit incrementally and still capped well below highs posted earlier in February. Chart impulses aside, latest reports about ramped up efforts to contain the Chinese virus outbreak have sapped some demand for safe-havens as stocks pare some losses, as Bunds hover around 174.37 vs 174.51 at best, Gilts flatline after edging a minor new Liffe peak at 134.42 and 10 year T-notes crest 131-00. However, Italian BTPs continue to lag after dire ip data and Fitch affirmed the sovereign’s BBB standing with a stable outlook, as expected.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures remain choppy as focus remains on OPEC’s move following a three-day meeting by the group’s JTC. In terms of the fallout, the committee reportedly proposed a 600k supply cut to start immediately which will continue through to June if agreed by all members and they expect Russia to respond in a matter of days according to sources, while there were twitter reports of unconfirmed chatter OPEC+ are proposing extending current cuts into year-end. That said, Russian Energy Minister Novak continued to push back against these cuts stating that Russia needs a few days to analyse situation on oil market and will come up next week with its position for OPEC+ meeting due next month, although Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov that he supports the panel’s proposal of cutting oil output – but did not specify a preferred magnitude of reductions. WTI and Brent futures have largely traded on either side of USD 51/bbl and USD 55/bbl respectively before prices moved lower in tandem with sentiment. Elsewhere, spot gold treads water just under USD 1570/oz with the yellow metal’s 21 DMA seen around 1564/oz. Meanwhile, copper prices saw brutal losses after hitting resistance at USD 2.6/lb (low USD 2.55/lb) with reports noting that Chinese copper traders, the metal’s largest market, asked miners to cancel or halt shipments of the red metal as the virus outbreak takes its toll on demand.

Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia is not yet prepared to announce its position on OPEC+ actions. In related news, Oman’s Oil Minister said he supports the output cut recommendations from the OPEC+ JTC, while there were separate comments from Azerbaijan’s Energy Minister who expects no early OPEC+ meeting and noted a February meeting was discussed and situation was analysed but the meeting will be held in March as planned. (Newswires)

PetroChina plans to reduce its crude throughput by 320k bpd for February due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

subject: Bunds: choppy trade either side of parity after post-NFP rebound
content: The 10 year German benchmark gapped higher at open and extended initial gains to 21 ticks overnight before fading alongside US Treasuries, but appears to have found a base just above 174.00 amidst ongoing Chinese virus jitters and following significantly firmer than forecast CPI data overnight. Bunds are now getting a mild lift from a downturn in EU stocks, but remain within recent ranges after stopping only 3 ticks shy of Friday’s apex (174.42). Ahead, Sentix Eurozone sentiment is due possibly at an earlier than usual time, and seen weaker.

content:
Air Liquide (AL FP) – Co. has strengthened its partnership with BASF (BAS GY) in Antwerp with three new long-term contracts. (Newswires)

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Co. is to collaborate with Meiogenix to accelerate agricultural innovation through the development of unique technologies. Separately, Co’s federal court cases in the US regarding the Roundup weedkillers have been pushed back at the request of mediator. (Newswires)

Burford Capital (BUR LN) – MuddyWaters have posted negative commentary on the Co’s H2 results, stating this validates their thesis that there are significant questions around their real value. (Twitter)

Carl Zeiss (AFX GY) – Q1 EBIT EUR 56.8mln vs. Prev. EUR 48.1mln. revenue EUR 370mln vs. Exp. EUR 363mln. EBIT margin 15.4% vs. Prev. 14.9% YY. (Newswires)

Intu Properties (INTU LN) – Co. notes that it engaged in constructive discussions relating to a proposed equity raise alongside Co’s FY results at the end of February. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM)/ Mediaset Espana (TL5 SM) – Mediaset is to submit revised plans to merge its Italian and Spanish broadcasting units, according to sources. (Newswires)

Nokia (NOKIA FH)/Ericsson (ERICB SS) – US NEC Director Kudlow says there is nothing which would prohibit US tech Co’s from acquiring either of the Co’s; added that the US is not in the business of purchasing Co’s. (Newswires)

NMC Health (NMC LN) – Co. is reportedly in talks with KKR regarding a potential deal, albeit sources note that Co’s volatile share price has made it difficult for KKR to set a price, which is seen around GBP 2bln, according to sources cited by The Mail on Sunday. The source added that KKR may face competition from other US-based PE firms for NMC Health. (Daily Mail) Elsewhere, Co. announce legal review to verify that total interests of non-executive chairman B.R. Shetty, his associated family members and associated family holding Co’s shares in NMC. Co. expects to report FY19 in-line with management expectations. (Newswires)

Roche (ROG SW) – Co notes that top-line results from investigator-led Phase II/III trial with Gantenerumab did not meet its primary endpoints in people who have early onset inherited form of Alzheimer’s disease. (Newswires) Co. has a 2.3% weighting in the Stoxx 600

SSAB (SSABB SS) – A block trade of ~SEK 1bln worth were printed after the close on Friday, with local speculation that government controlled LKAB bought the shares. (Newswires)

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) –  Co’s head of steel division is to leave at the end of the month. (Handelsblatt)

MTU Aero Engines (MTX GY) – Co. expects Boeing (BA) to offer two jet engines for the successor model to its 737 plane. (Newswires)

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

10th February 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac stocks began the week with a sombre tone due to concerns regarding the ongoing coronavirus epidemic which has surpassed the death toll from the SARS outbreak, and following last Friday’s losses on Wall St where markets pulled back from record highs but still notched the best weekly performance since June last year. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s tech and energy sectors although downside in the index was stemmed by resilience in gold miners and defensives, while the Tokyo benchmark recouped some of the opening losses on favourable currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were cautious due to the rising infected numbers and as some businesses resumed operations, although the mainland showed some early resilience amid continued PBoC efforts including the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus and CNY 900bln of reverse repo operations to sustain liquidity levels.

FTSE 100

BT (BT/A LN)/Vodafone (VOD LN) – A full ban on Huawei within the UK’s 5G network could cost leading UK telecom operators an estimated USD 1.5bln, as well as delaying the network expansion by up to two-years. (Times)

Centrica (CNA LN) – Sarwjit Sambhi, head of the Co’s consumer business, is said to be front-running for the next CEO position, according to sources cited by The Telegraph. (Telegraph)

NMC Health (NMC LN) – Co. is reportedly in talks with KKR regarding a potential deal, albeit sources note that Co’s volatile share price has made it difficult for KKR to set a price, which is seen around GBP 2bln, according to sources cited by The Mail on Sunday. The source added that KKR may face competition from other US-based PE firms for NMC Health. (Daily Mail)

Carnival (CCL LN) - Japanese cruise ship has about 60 more coronavirus infections to bring the total to 130. (Newswires)

Royal Mail (RMG LN) – Co. has made a three-year contract proposal to the CWU union who voted in October for strike actions over problems with pay and conditions. (Newswires)

Lloyds (LLOY LN) – Almost 1/3 of staff at the Co. state they are struggling financially, as well as almost half of respondents saying they are concerned they may lose their job, according to a 2019 poll using members of the Unite union. (Guardian)

Telecom Names – Senior Conservatives have written to Conservative MPs highlighting concerns around Huawei’s role in the UK’s 5G network, wanting ‘high risk’ Co’s to be ruled out immediately or alternatively phased out over time. Subsequently, China’s UK ambassador to the UK has criticised these comments, and the 35% cap that has been placed on Huawei’s involvement in the 5G network. (BBC)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

William Hill (WMH LN) – Co. is said to be close to signing a media deal after reviving talks with CBS Sport. The parties are reportedly in the final stages of negotiations with an announcement said to be imminent. (Times) 

Asos (ASC LN) – Co’s CEO has increased his stake by the purchase of circa. 1.6k shares. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

WHITBREAD (WTB LN) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY) – Co. is expected to cut ~15k jobs (Prev. ~10k jobs), with savings to exceed EUR 1.4bln, according to Handelsblatt citing sources. (Handelsblatt)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co. has announced the delaying of reopening of some Chinese plants. (Newswires)

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Co. has become the official development partner of SAP (SAP GY) to drive innovative customer experiences. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) – PE firms are reportedly offering sweeteners in an attempt win over Germany’s IG Metall union regarding the Thyssenkrupp elevator sale. Three PE bidders, who valued the division at ~EUR 15.5bln, are said to be prepared to offer job guarantees to the union, according to sources. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

GERRESHEIMER (GXI GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. is said to be in talks to acquire Bombardier’s stake in the A220 program (~34% stake) in a deal which could be announced as soon as this week, according to sources. Sources added that negotiations are at an advanced stage. A value was not mentioned by Bombardier invested over USD 6bln in the A220’s development before surrendering control to Airbus two years ago. (Newswires) For reference, both Cos are scheduled to report earnings on Feb 13th.

Axa (CS FP) – Co. has confirmed that it is to sell its Central and Eastern European operations for EUR 1bln. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air-France (AF FP) – Reports January passenger numbers +2.2%, traffic +2.7%. January passenger load factor +0.3ppt to 86.1%. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE 

Insurance Names – Covea is reportedly in discussions regarding the acquisition of PartnerRe in an all cash deal valued at USD 9bln; could be agreed in the next few months., according to individuals close to the discussion. (FT) Possibly of note for Exor (EXO IM) as they control ParterRe following a USD 6.9bln acquisition in 2016.

ArcelorMittal (MT NA) – Co. is said to mull the closure of the Seremange-Erzange coking plant. (Newswires)

Buzzi Unicem (BZU IM) – FY19 revenue EUR 3.2bln vs. Exp. EUR 3.2bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CNH INDUSTRIAL (CNHI IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

JULIUS BAER (BAER SW) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

NORSK HYDRO (NHY NO) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

NORSK HYDRO (NHY NO) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

VESTAS WIND SYSTEMS (VWS DC) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN CHASE

US

Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 10th February 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asia-Pac stocks began the week with a sombre tone as the death toll for the Coronavirus has now surpassed that of SARS
  • China’s total confirmed cases now stands at 40171 and total deaths at 908 as of February 9th
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia is not yet prepared to announce its position on OPEC+ actions
  • UK Foreign Minister Raab said a Singapore deal will be one of the first wave of free trade agreements and wants a deal over the line ASAP
  • EU member states are reportedly toughening their demands for 'status quo' access to UK fishing waters post-Brexit, according to the Telegraph
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Norwegian CPI, Eurozone Sentix Index, Fed’s Daly and Harker

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

China confirmed 3062 new coronavirus cases and 97 deaths on February 9th vs. 2656 new cases and 89 deaths on February 8th, with the total confirmed cases now at 40171 and total deaths at 908 as of February 9th. (Newswires)

Japan cruise ship has about 60 more coronavirus infections to bring the total to 130. (Newswires)

China is spending at least USD 10bln to control the coronavirus outbreak and is reaching out for medical supplies from other nations, while it was also reported that the World Health Organization is sending an advanced team to China to investigate the coronavirus. (Newswires)

National Institute of Health's Fauci said there have been "no glitches" so far in coronavirus vaccine development with Moderna (MRNA) and if that continues, he expects phase 1 trial in people could start within 2.5 months. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac stocks began the week with a sombre tone due to concerns regarding the ongoing coronavirus epidemic which has surpassed the death toll from the SARS outbreak, and following last Friday’s losses on Wall St where markets pulled back from record highs but still notched the best weekly performance since June last year. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s tech and energy sectors although downside in the index was stemmed by resilience in gold miners and defensives, while the Tokyo benchmark recouped some of the opening losses on favourable currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were cautious due to the rising infected numbers and as some businesses resumed operations, although the mainland showed some early resilience amid continued PBoC efforts including the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus and CNY 900bln of reverse repo operations to sustain liquidity levels. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher amid the cautious risk appetite in the region and with the BoJ present in the market in which it upped the purchases in 10yr-25yr maturities.   

PBoC injected CNY 700bln via 7-day and CNY 200bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position, while the PBoC announced to offer the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus on Monday and will offer the facility weekly to banks later in the month. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.9863 vs. Exp. 6.9829 (Prev. 6.9768)

China Global Times tweeted a good number of Chinese companies will scoop back to business operations although companies need to take the safety of their workers as the top priority, while it later tweeted that many SMEs in China will not restart business today due to shortage of protective supplies. (Twitter)

Chinese CPI (Jan) Y/Y 5.4% vs. Exp. 4.9% (Prev. 4.5%) Chinese PPI (Jan) Y/Y 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. -0.5%)

UK/EU

UK Foreign Minister Raab said a Singapore deal will be one of the first wave of free trade agreements and wants a deal over the line ASAP, while Raab also stated the UK plans to start trade negotiations with Japan before spring and complete an FTA by year-end. In related news, the UK is reportedly planning to announce locations of as many as 10 freeports this year. (Newswires) EU member states are reportedly toughening their demands for 'status quo' access to UK fishing waters post-Brexit. (Telegraph) Norwegian PM Soldberg has warned Britain that Brexit should not be utilised as an opportunity to shut out other countries from fishing in British waters. (Politico)

UK PM Johnson is expected, on Tuesday, to announce his decision on the HS2 rail line; with UK Sunday Papers reporting that the London to Birmingham section will go ahead, but remaining sections will be under review. Separately, a Cabinet reshuffle is expected to occur prior to the Easter recess on Thursday. (Politico)

UK Chancellor Javid is considering a large tax increase on higher earners in the March budget. (FT) Furthermore, the Chancellor is also considering limiting tax relief on pension contributions to 20% and introducing a “recurring” wealth tax on the owners of expensive homes. (Telegraph)

Senior Conservative’s have written to Conservative MPs highlighting concerns around Huawei’s role in the UK’s 5G network, wanting ‘high risk’ Co’s to be ruled out immediately or alternatively phased out over time. Subsequently, China’s UK ambassador to the UK has criticised these comments, and the 35% cap that has been placed on Huawei’s involvement in the 5G network. (BBC)

The “Boris bounce” will be dampened by the disruption caused to the global economy from the coronavirus outbreak, economists have warned. (Telegraph)

EU’s efforts to hammer out a budget deal by the end of February is reportedly at risk of being de-railed by widening divisions between richer and poorer member states, according to diplomats. European Council President Michel is convening an EU leaders’ summit on February 20th in an attempt to negotiate on the seven-year EU budget - which must be settled by year-end. (FT)

Irish PM Varadkar’s Fine Gael party is seen taking 36 seats, while Fianna Fail is seen to win 45 seats and Sinn Fein at 37 seats in Ireland’s snap general election. (Newswires)

ECB’s de Guindos says we have tools and willingness to use them if necessary. We can lower interest rates further, increase the volume of debt purchases or increase liquidity injections, but the side effects are increasingly evident. That is why we continually insist that it is now up to other actors to come into play. (ECB)

Fitch affirmed Italy at 'BBB'; Outlook stable and affirmed Russia at 'BBB'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

FX

DXY was rangebound near YTD highs after the recent firmer than expected US Non-Farm Payrolls and Average Earnings data. The greenback also found a floor due to the subdued trade in its transatlantic counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD around 1.0950 and 1.2900 respectively amid continued Brexit anxiety as EU member states were reportedly toughening their demands for 'status quo' access to UK fishing waters post-Brexit, while France is also demanding the UK aligns with EU rules permanently in return for a trade deal. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses nursed some of their recent losses and antipodeans were slightly firmer heading into this week’s RBNZ meeting where OIS price in 92% chance for rates to be kept unchanged, while AUD/USD attempted a reclaim of the 0.6700 handle after firmer than expected Chinese inflation data and with PPI at its first increase in 7 months. TRY was the outperformer overnight after the nation’s banking regulator reduced limit for banks’ forex transactions which saw USD/TRY gap below the 6.00 handle which later acted as resistance for the pair.

Turkey banking watchdog BDDK said it was lowering the limit for Turkish banks’ forex swap, spot and forward transactions with foreign entities to 10% of a bank’s equity from Prev. 25%. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures pressured at the open to below USD 50/bbl following comments from Azerbaijan’s Energy Minister who pushed back against holding an early OPEC+ meeting, while Russian Energy Minister Novak also noted that Russia is not yet prepared to reveal its stance regarding measures. However, prices then gradually recovered throughout the session given the lack of any material change to ongoing narrative with oil prices heading into European open relatively unchanged. Elsewhere, gold was rangebound amid similar price action in the greenback, while copper nursed some of the recent losses despite the risk aversion with prices benefitting as Chinese factories began to resume production.    

Baker Hughes (7th Feb): Oil +1 at 676, Nat. gas -1 at 111, total unchanged at 790. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak stated that Russia is not yet prepared to announce its position on OPEC+ actions. In related news, Oman’s Oil Minister said he supports the output cut recommendations from the OPEC+ JTC, while there were separate comments from Azerbaijan’s Energy Minister who expects no early OPEC+ meeting and noted a February meeting was discussed and situation was analysed but the meeting will be held in March as planned. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are set to begin oil production in their neutral zone at an initial level of 10k BPD (500k BPD capacity), according to sources. (WSJ)

PetroChina plans to reduce its crude throughput by 320k bpd for February due to the coronavirus. (Newswires

 

US 

The Treasury curve bull-flattened on Friday, ahead of the weekend, amid coronavirus concerns overshadowing the strong US January jobs report. The T-Note was initially offered on the headline NFP print (+225k vs. exp. +160k), with desks noting an “algo drilled” move lower before real money and CTAs swiftly moving into cover shorts, prompting the reversal higher. Participants are likely eager to reduce their risk exposure over the weekend; a growing chorus of US corporates have been noting potential financial impacts from the coronavirus in their guidance and the number of cases/deaths continues to rise in China, seeing further quarantine measures in the APAC region. One desk highlights the bull flattening particularly interesting ahead of the duration-heavy Treasury issuance next week (3s, 10s and 30s), which, ceteris paribus, would lead to a bear steepener. By settlement, the 10-year yield had fallen by just north of 6bps to 1.58%, with the curve generally flatter: 2s5s -1.3bps, 2s10s -1.6bps, 2s30s -1.8bps. US T-note futures (H20) settled 16+ ticks higher at 131-02+.

NEC Director Kudlow said US companies are flexible and adept when asked how worried the administration is regarding the impact to production from the coronavirus, while he added that this is principally a China problem. (VOA)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia begins cautious as coronavirus deaths surpass SARS and following the pullback in US stocks from record highs
content:
Asia-Pac markets begin the week with a sombre tone due to concerns regarding the ongoing coronavirus epidemic which surpassed the death toll from the SARS outbreak, and following last Friday’s losses on Wall St where markets pulled back from record highs but still notched the best weekly performance since June last year. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.2%) are subdued with underperformance seen in Australia’s tech and energy sectors although downside in the index is stemmed by resilience in gold miners and defensives, while the Tokyo benchmark has recouped most its opening losses on favourable currency flows. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) are cautious due to the rising infected numbers and with some businesses resuming operations, although the mainland has shown some resilience amid continued PBoC efforts including the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus and CNY 900bln of reverse repo operations to sustain liquidity levels.

In FX markets, the DXY is rangebound near YTD highs after the recent firmer than expected US Non-Farm Payrolls and Average Earnings data. The greenback also found a floor due to the subdued trade in its transatlantic counterparts with EUR/USD and GBP/USD around 1.0950 and 1.2900 respectively amid continued Brexit anxiety as EU member states are reportedly toughening their demands for 'status quo' access to UK fishing waters post-Brexit, while France is also demanding the UK aligns with EU rules permanently in return for a trade deal. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses nurse recent losses and antipodeans are slightly firmer heading into this week’s RBNZ meeting where OIS price in 92% chance for rates to be kept unchanged, while AUD/USD attempts a reclaim of the 0.6700 handle after firmer than expected Chinese inflation data and with PPI at its first increase in 7-months.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher amid the cautious risk appetite in the region and with the BoJ present in the market in which it upped purchases in 10yr-25yr maturities.

analysis_details: • As a guide, this represents a increase in 10yr-25yr buying from a previous of JPY 100bln

subject: PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: Coronavirus surpasses SARS deathtoll
content:
China Merchants Shekou Industrial Zone (001979 CH) - Co. January contracted sales rose 0.9% Y/Y to CNY 11.9bln. (Newswires)

China Overseas Grand Oceans (81 HK) - Co. Chairman Yan Jianguo resigned. (Newswires)

Luye Pharma Group (2186 HK) - Co. unit signed distribution and marketing service agreement with Cipla Medro South Africa. (Newswires)

New Hope Luhe (000876 CH) - Co. January hog sales rose 161% Y/Y to CNY 1.1bln. (Newswires)

PBoC - PBoC is to offer the first round of special re-lending funds for tackling the coronavirus on Monday and will offer the facility weekly to banks later in the month. In related news, PBoC Deputy Governor Pan reiterated the central bank will maintain ample liquidity and deepen interest rate reform. (Newswires) 

Coronavirus

China confirmed 3062 new coronavirus cases and 97 deaths on February 9th vs. 2656 new cases and 89 deaths on February 8th, while total confirmed cases is now at 40171 and total deaths at 908 as of February 9th. (Newswires)

China is spending at least USD 10bln to control the coronavirus outbreak and is reaching out for medical supplies from other nations, while it was also reported that the World Health Organization is sending an advanced team to China to investigate the coronavirus. (Newswires)

US coronavirus task force expect to see more cases in the US, but the current risk to US citizens is low, while there were separate comments from US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US is prepared to spend up to USD 100mln to assist China and other coronavirus impacted countries. (Newswires)

NIH's Fauci said there have been "no glitches" so far in coronavirus vaccine development with Moderna (MRNA) and if that continues, he expects phase 1 trial in people could start within 2.5 months. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said Chinese President Xi reassured US President Trump that despite delays, China will be meeting its targets for the agreed purchases of US goods under the Phase One Deal and that there are no tensions between US and China over coronavirus. Kudlow also stated that he sees “absolutely minimal” impact of coronavirus on the US economy which could cut US GDP growth by 0.2ppts. Kudlow also said that US companies are flexible and adept when asked how worried the administration is in regards to production worries from the coronavirus, while he added that this is principally a China problem. (VOA)

China Global Times tweeted a good number of Chinese companies will scoop back to business operations although companies need to take the safety of their workers as the top priority. (Twitter)

 

Other News

China Customs Office said they are to combine the months of January and February for reporting of trade data amid the lack of prelim trade data. (Newswires)

China’s Agricultural Ministry announced a new H5N6 bird flu case in the Sichuan province. (Newswires)

Large US tech firms are reportedly seeking alternative to Hong Kong as an internet hub after US regulators blocked a data cable plan. (Newswires)

Data Recap - Hong Kong Foreign Reserves (USD)(Jan) 445.9B (Prev. 441.3B)

subject: PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE STOCK NEWS: Advantech (2395 TT) January rev. fell 5.1% Y/Y to TWD 3.96bln

SINGAPORE

Other News - MAS advised financial institutions to take additional precautions after the government increased its alert level regarding the outbreak. (Newswires)
